entry.title: Re: Implementing a Dynamic YTD Filter Up to Yesterday in...
entry.content:
Dear Moritz,

I am not sure, if you are using a date field with day granularity in your model. If you do so, you could use the option to set an own current date variable (for instance, when you create your first restricted measure:

Then, you need to uncheck the system current date check box, so the "current date" is not derived by the system date:

After that you need to insert the following code to automatically update the Current Date on page initialization:

// set current date variable
var yesterday = new Date();
yesterday.setDate(yesterday.getDate() - 1);


// convert date to CurrentDateTime
Application.setCurrentDateTime(
    CurrentDateTime.createCalendarDateTime({
        granularity: CalendarTimeGranularity.Day,
		day: yesterday.getDate(),
        month: yesterday.getMonth()+1, // month is indexed 0-11
        year: yesterday.getFullYear()
    })
);

It will auto update the current date to yesterday. You could use the current date for all your measures.

Kind regards,

Tano

entry.title: Free of Charge Material from Customer with Freight and Import Duty cost to be captured in COGM
entry.content:
Dear All,

Currently I'm facing with a requirement from our client as per below,

When produce a specific product, sometimes they will received a Raw Material as FOC to produce the SFG and FG then sell to the Customer.
When receive those FOC RM, they will bear the cost such as Freight and Import duty.

Question from my end, how we are able to capture such cost since the material is FOC which is a non valuated material and only track for the qty in the system.

But during run the standard cost estimate by our costing team, they should be able to read the information related to Freight and Import duty as a cost structure.
The goals is to track the cost that was coming from Freight and Import duty for those FOC material during run standard cost estimate from Controlling team.

Anyone have such experience ?

Kindly please advise or any suggestion will be appreciated.

entry.title: Shaping the Future of Utilities Together: Advisory Customer Council for Utilities 2025
entry.content:
In today’s fast-evolving world, success is built on connection. When great minds come together, we unlock the power to shape the future together. That spirit of collaboration was at the heart of the Advisory Customer Council for Utilities (ACCU), held on October 1–2, 2025 in Walldorf. This exclusive forum brought together senior executives from leading utility companies and SAP leadership for two days of strategic dialogue, innovation, and co-creation.

A Forum for Strategic Engagement

The ACCU is more than just a meeting,  it's a platform for trusted exchange, visionary thinking, and shaping the future of SAP’s solutions for the utilities sector. This exclusive forum fosters alignment on industry priorities and enables participants to influence SAP’s roadmap in a meaningful way.

Highlights from the Event

We kicked off with a warm and engaging get-together on Day 0, setting the tone for a productive and inspiring agenda. Over the next two days, we heard powerful customer stories from Zelestra, BC Hydro, and E.ON, each offering unique perspectives and insights into their transformation journeys.

SAP leaders shared updates on key topics including:

  • Clean Core
  • SAP Business Technology Platform (BDC)
  • Artificial Intelligence
  • Customer Support & Experience
  • Move to the Cloud
  • Asset Management
  • Distributed Energy Resources

These sessions sparked valuable discussions and reinforced our shared commitment to innovation and excellence.

A Special Moment

A standout moment of the event was the participation of SAP CEO Christian Klein, who joined us for an open conversation. His presence and clear commitment to the utilities industry underscored SAP’s dedication to supporting our customers through this era of transformation.

Experiencing Innovation Firsthand

Participants had the opportunity to visit the SAP Experience Center, where we showcased the SAP Energy Park, a space that highlights SAP as a living example of sustainability in action. Through interactive exhibits and hands-on demonstrations, participants discovered how SAP’s latest solutions are driving the transition to net zero, bringing the future of utilities to life in a dynamic and inspiring environment.

Looking Ahead

We extend our heartfelt thanks to all our customers for their trust, insights, and active participation. Your voices are instrumental in shaping the future of SAP’s utilities solutions. We look forward to continuing this journey together—co-innovating, collaborating, and leading the way into the next era of utilities.

entry.title: Re: The installation of SAP products failed with 5 error(s)
entry.content: Hello! It’s been a while since you posted were you able to resolve it? I ran into the same issue and wanted to share what fixed it for me. The problem was fonts: exceptions were caused by user-installed fonts rather than the system defaults. If you remove the user-installed fonts, delete the SAP-related folders, and then reinstall SAP GUI, it should be resolved.

entry.title: Re: WHEN CREATING A NEW CARD, NOT ALL MDF SUCCESSFACTORS...
entry.content:
Hi Jhonatan,

Please see https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/implementing-metadata-framework-mdf/mdf-configurations-for-latest-people-profile?locale=en-US

There can be few reason why a MDF object does not show up in the list 

1. The object you are trying to add is already as card into one or other category 

2. If the object is pre-delivered 

3. If object has more than 2 level of composite (parent + child + grand child is allowed) those are not allowed 

Please help check if it is due to any of these reasons.

Regards,

-Narendra

entry.title: Re: The installation of SAP products failed with 5 error(s)
entry.content: Hello! It’s been a while since you posted—were you able to resolve it? I ran into the same issue and wanted to share what fixed it for me. The problem was fonts: exceptions were caused by user-installed fonts rather than the system defaults. If you remove the user-installed fonts, delete the SAP-related folders, and then reinstall SAP GUI, it should be resolved.

{"error":{"code":"bpm.workflowruntime.rest.user.not.sufficient.privileges","message":"User does not have sufficient privileges.","logId":"40ff78b6-14e4-40fa-91ec-17d6afe-ap21"}}

entry.title: SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025
entry.content:
Hi folks,

SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now also available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025.
The ABAP AI license materials for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 are the same as for SAP BTP ABAP Environment & SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For more information, please check out the following SAP Note 3571857.

Below, you can find a step-by-step guide on how to activate SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 system.

Have fun and stay tuned for TechEd soon!

Best,
Sebastian

 

Prerequisites

You have a customer account on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and a development system on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and you have prepared the following:

  • Subscription to SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Subscription to SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities
  • Established trust to your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant in your BTP Subaccount, see this link
  • Your user needs Administrator access to your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant
  • Your system needs to be configured so that it trusts server certificates according to the "required" section of the BTP Trust Store.
  • Your system needs to use a client certificate issued by a CA listed in the "required" section of the BTP Trust Store. One way to obtain a client certificate can be found on Manage Destination Certificates (under "Generate a Certificate").
  • You've successfully applied SAP Note 3627794 .
  • Your ABAP system needs to support TLS 1.3. If TLS 1.3 is not enabled, refer to SAP Note 3318423  to activate it.

 

Configuration steps in your SAP BTP subaccount

  1. In your BTP subaccount, navigate to Entitlements. You’ll see a table with all entitlements it already has.
  2. Select Configure Entitlements > Add Service Plans. A popover appears with all entitlements available for your directory/subaccount.
  3. Select the service SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities and then the plan “default”
  4. Select the amount of quota
  5. Select Add Service Plans.
  6. Select Save.

 

  1. Navigate to your subaccount in the SAP BTP cockpit
  2. Go to Services > Service Marketplace.
  3. Choose the SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities tile.
  4. Choose Create and select Plan default




  5. Once the service is created, go to your IAS and navigate to Users & Authorizations > Groups
  6. Check that the group j4d-admin was successfully created
  7. Add your admin user to the created j4a-admin group

     

  8. Navigate to your subaccount in the SAP BTP cockpit
  9. In the navigation go to Services >Instances & Subscriptions
  10. Choose the SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities tile.
  11. Click on Go to Application




  12. Maintain Certificate Mappings app should be opened



    Configuration in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 system

    1. Go to your ABAP system, open the transaction APPLDESTCC
    2. Select scenario HTTP - Application Destination and click on Execute


    3. Next, select AIC_ADT_HTTP_PROXY and open the context menu. Choose Create New Application Destination. Now, you're asked to enter the details of your application destination.


       



    4. Enter an Application Destination Name of your choice and select the check mark. 



    5. Now, first enter a Description and select the checkboxes Active and Default.

    6. Fill in the information in the Technical Settings tab:
      1. Target System Settings: In the Host field, enter https://proxy.<your region>.hub.j4a.services.sap. As Protocol, select HTTPS.
      2. (Optional) HTTP Proxy Options: This information is not mandatory.

        Note The region you enter in https://proxy.<your region>.hub.j4a.services.sap must be the same region (not technical key) that you chose for your subaccount, for example "eu10". See Regions and API Endpoints for the ABAP Environment


         

    7. Choose the Logon tab
      1. General Settings: Select Connection to External Server.
      2. Logon Procedure: Select Client Certificate and choose the certificate you wish to use from the dropdown menu
      3. Select Save. You've successfully maintained the connection.

         

    8. Now, continue in your subaccount in the SAP BTP Cockpit
      1. Select the SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities subscription you have just created (see Subscribing to SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities), or open its details and select Go to Application. You are forwarded to the Maintain Certificate Mappings page.
      2. In the Certificate Mappings section, select Create to receive a one-time password (OTP).
      3. Copy the OTP.

        Note: the OTP is valid for five minutes. If you need a new one, close the pop-up and click on Create again.


    9.  Go to your corresponding ABAP system and run report AIC_ADT_PROXY_CERTIFICATE. Select Execute.
      1. Paste the one-time password that you've copied in the previous step
      2. (Optional) If you wish to use a new certificate that you haven't used in step 1, select Use Custom SSL Client PSE ID. Click in the Client PSE ID field and choose the new certificate from the value help. Now, you can go back to step 1 and switch to the new certificate.
      3. Select Execute



      4. You've successfully registered your certificate!




         

 You can now create a new ABAP Project in ADT (using its latest version) and check out SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities

entry.title: SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, 2025 FPS00 – What’s New
entry.content:
We have recently released the latest updates for SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, 2025 FPS00. With this release, we further expand the AI capabilities available for SAP EWM, add in more functionalities and scenarios for the Advanced Shipping & Receiving integration, deliver a host of extensibility and user experience improvements, improve the Quality Management and Production integrations, and much more.

ADVANCED SHIPPING & RECEIVING

Integration between transportation and warehouse logistics is a significant contributor towards logistics efficiency, synchronizing process changes between warehouse and transportation, reducing overall logistics-costs by optimizing and streamlining freight planning with warehouse execution. To further tighten this integration, with this release we provide the following enhancements and updates to Advanced Shipping & Receiving. Cross-Delivery Handling Units

With this feature, you can use cross-delivery handling units (HUs) in the outbound process with Advanced Shipping and Receiving. The deliveries that are packed together must fulfill several conditions. The system runs the checks when you set the status of the delivery to Ready for Shipping, or in the case of immediate loading, when you set the status of the HUs to Packed for Shipping.

The cross-delivery HUs must meet the following conditions in SAP EWM:

  • All the deliveries involved must have transportation planning type E or F
  • All deliveries have the same ship-to party
  • Either all the deliveries are relevant for immediate loading or none of them are
  • You must set the status Ready for Shipping for all the outbound delivery orders involved in the cross-delivery network at the same time. The checks on all HUs or deliveries must be OK to set the status.
  • All the deliveries involved must have status Picking Completed before you set the status Ready for Shipping.

Transportation Management performs checks for shipping points, loading points, doors, and other transport related attributes on the cross-delivery HUs. For more information, see Integration of Cross-Delivery Handling Units in Advanced Shipping and Receiving.

You can use cross-delivery HUs in the warehouse driven process (transportation type E) and the transport driven process (transportation type F)

If you are using immediate loading, you can reverse the status Packed for Shipping for a cross-delivery HU if this HU is not yet loaded and Ready for Shipping is not set. You can reverse the status Ready for Shipping even if loading HUs has already started.

Harmonized Outbound Delivery Update in Logistics Execution

With this feature, we ensure that the changes in Logistic Execution process are harmonized across ERP Logistics Execution (LE), Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and Transportation Management (TM). For example:

  • You can change specific values of an outbound delivery in LE after the outbound delivery is distributed to EWM. Any changes you make in LE outbound delivery are automatically distributed to EWM and TM.
  • You can also add more items to an outbound delivery in LE after the delivery is distributed to EWM and freight units are created in TM.

In addition, some fields might be read-only in Change Outbound Delivery, depending on the warehouse processing status of the outbound delivery. For example, if the delivery has the status Ready for Warehouse Processing, some fields might not be editable in Change Outbound Delivery. To see the full list of the fields that are editable please read the Help Portal page “Updating Outbound Deliveries in Logistics Execution”.

Enablement of Stock Transport Order Execution for the inbound process in embedded EWM

This feature enables you to process stock transport orders (STO) for sending and receiving warehouses in one Freight Order across EWM managed warehouses and non-EWM managed MM-IM storage locations, provided that embedded EWM/TM is used. Such STO enables the transfer of goods and materials from one plant to another within the same company code (intra-company).

In a two-step STO process, outbound and inbound deliveries are created, and the freight units (FU) are reassigned from the outbound to the inbound delivery. The posting of goods issue triggers the creation of an inbound delivery and the automatic reassignment of the FU from the outbound to the inbound delivery.

As soon as the FU is assigned the inbound delivery as its predecessor document, the receiving processes such as check-in, unloading and goods receipt can be processed.

This feature provides visibility throughout the end-to-end process – from sending shipping point to receiving point within one business document. This feature is only available in embedded EWM and TM deployment.

New Handling Execution Status: Cargo Ready for Loading

With this feature, we introduce a new execution status Cargo Ready for Loading, which, starts the creation of customs invoice and export declaration before the goods are loaded onto a truck in an Advanced Shipping and Receiving process.

The status is available on the freight order (FO) maintenance UI in Transportation Management (TM). When in use, you can set the status after the warehouse processing status is set to Completed. The status precedes handling execution status Loading Completed and can be configured as a prerequisite to customs documents requests. You can revert the status any time before the customs documents have been created.

Additionally, you can set up your system so that automatic consignment order creation happens when the status is set. Similarly, you can configure it so that the status triggers output processing such as the printing of transport documents or advanced shipping notifications (ASN). To find out more please read the Help Portal page “New Handling Execution Status: Cargo Ready for Loading”.

INTEGRATION

Integration is a core pillar of our investments, by which we provide a deep and native integration with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud solution components, along with SAP's cloud offerings for seamless integration of comprehensive logistics end-to-end processes incl. production integration, dangerous goods handling, customs processing and more. To that end, in this release we deliver the following enhancements.

Partial Goods Issue for Component Consumption & COGI split

With this feature, if you use synchronous goods movements for the consumption of components by manufacturing, you can split the goods issue for components consumed from EWM-managed storage locations if less than the full quantity needed is available on the production staging area (PSA). The system posts the goods issue for the available quantities and posts the remaining quantity to the Reprocess Goods Movements app (COGI). This feature is only available in embedded EWM.

The following restrictions apply to the COGI-split available with SAP S/4HANA 2025, FPS0:

  • You can't use this feature to split goods issue for components that require serial numbers.
  • You can't use this feature to split goods issue for batch-managed components.

To split goods issue quantities, you must activate it in one of the following Customizing activities:

  • For Repetitive Manufacturing, in Customizing for Production under Repetitive Manufacturing > Control > Define Repetitive Manufacturing Profiles
  • For Discrete Manufacturing, in Customizing for Production under Shop Floor Control > Master Data > Define Production Scheduling Profile for Discrete Manufacturing
  • For Process Manufacturing, in Customizing for Production Planning for Process Industries under Process Order > Master Data > Define Production Scheduling Profile for Process Manufacturing

EWM/QM Serial Number Integration

This feature enables you to record a quality inspection result for a specific serialized product in the Quality Management (QM) component of SAP S/4HANA by recording a usage decision for the serialized product with reference to its serial number. The system integrates the serial number to the inspection lot in the QM component during the goods receipt posting of the stock item. Note that this feature is available only for inspection object type (IOT) Q-Inspection Product/Batch Inbound Del. (IOT 4) and Q-Inspection Product/Batch Whse-Internal (IOT 5).

To enable this feature, you select the checkbox Serial No. Integr. (Enable Serial Number Integration) for IOT 4 or IOT 5 in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Cross-Process Settings > Quality Management > Basics and Integration > Define and Activate Warehouse-Dependent IOTs.

For more information on recording a quality inspection result for a specific serialized product in the Quality Management (QM) component of SAP S/4HANA, please read the Help Portal page “Serial Numbers in Inspection Results”.

Deactivation of Quality Inspections Based on Movement Type

With this feature, you can deactivate quality inspections for inspection object type (IOT) Q-Inspection Product/Batch Inbound Del. (IOT 4) based on movement type settings in the Quality Management (QM) component of SAP S/4HANA. If the quality inspections are deactivated, the system doesn’t create an inspection request (inspection document or inspection lot).

The inspection process in EWM must be integrated with the QM component.

  • The QM component is in SAP S/4HANA 2025 or later.
  • You’ve deactivated quality inspections for the movement type in Customizing for Quality Management under Quality Inspection > Inspection Lot Creation > Inspection for Goods Movement.
  • You’ve deactivated quality inspections for IOT 4 based on movement type settings in the QM component.

To do this, you select the checkbox QM Deact. MvmtTyp (Deactivate Inspections Based on QM Movement Type Settings) in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Cross-Process Settings > Quality Management > Basics and Integration > Define and Activate Warehouse-Dependent IOTs. For additional information, please consult the Help Portal page “Deactivation of Quality Inspections Based On Movement Type”.

SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition and SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences integration

Support the integration of SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition and SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences for both embedded and decentralized extended warehouse management.

The following integration scenarios are provided for SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Science integration:

  • Read the handling units with inspection lots from SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition and SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences.
  • Stock the posting from SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences to SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition based on inspection decision on handling units.

Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

With this feature, you can integrate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with decentralized SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition.

You can use this integration if you want to start a business process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition but also want to use features that are available only in decentralized EWM based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. Learn more about integration aspects and supported features via our SAP blog  

The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Integration and the Knowledge Base Article “3376453 - SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, FPS01, FPS02 and FPS03: Release information and restrictions for EWM in SAP S/4HANA”.

EXTENSIBILITY & USABILITY

The Clean Core Extensibility strategy aims to provide a modern and powerful integration option for customers and partners. Alongside supporting this strategy, we continuously adapt solution content to modernize and simplify the user experience. By regularly updating and refining SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, we ensure we remain relevant and effective in meeting current needs. This year’s October release we deliver the following updates.

Monitor, RFUI, Interfaces enhancements

  • Warehouse Order Splitting in the Pick by Cart App - With this feature, you can use the Pick by Cart app to split a warehouse order when you've only partially completed a picking task. If you need to leave the warehouse order with only some items picked, you can choose to first unload the handling unit at its destination location and automatically split the warehouse order or just split the warehouse order. This helps you to more efficiently hand over the picking task to another warehouse worker.

  • Screen Zooming on Radio Frequency Devices - With this feature, you can enable zooming of radio frequency (RF) screens on presentation devices when using SAP GUI for HTML. For example, you can enable automatic zooming or fixed factor zooming of between 50 and 300 percent. You use zooming to fit RF screens to the display of the presentation device as well as possible. For more information please read the Help Portal page “Screen Zooming on Radio Frequency Devices”.

API updates: ODATA Services

  •  Posting changes in Physical Stock - With this feature you can perform several posting changes for the stock in your warehouse. You can make the following changes to the stock:
    • Change the stock type
    • Change the party entitled to dispose
    • Change product or batch
    • Change sales order or project reference
    • Change stock owner and usage

  • Visibility of Custom Fields in OData APIs – With this feature, you can use the Custom Fields app to make your custom fields appear in the OData APIs Warehouse Inbound Delivery and Warehouse Outbound Delivery Order, if your custom fields also appear in the business contexts Warehouse Request Header or Warehouse Request Item. You still use the Custom Fields app to add custom fields to Warehouse Request Header and Warehouse Inbound Delivery.
  • Warehouse Order Business Events – With this feature, the Warehouse Order business object triggers the following events when processing the warehouse tasks of a warehouse order:
    • Warehouse task created
    • Warehouse task confirmed
    • Warehouse task canceled
    • Warehouse task activated

Events are not triggered retroactively for existing warehouse orders and warehouse tasks. Events for warehouse tasks are triggered only when new warehouse tasks are processed or changes are made to existing warehouse orders and warehouse tasks (for example, a confirmation or cancellation).

API updates: Internal API

  • Enhancements to Goods Movements in EWM and Inventory Management – With this feature, you can now use the application programming interface (API) API for Goods Movement in EWM and IM (/SCWM/IF_API_IM_GOODSMVT) to post goods receipt with reference to purchase order items (standard and stock transfer items), order items, and their reversals. The API enables you to post goods movements (goods receipts, goods issues, transfer postings, and their reversals) in Inventory Management and Extended Warehouse Management for embedded warehouses. The new goods movements can be posted for unpacked or packed items, including nested and mixed handling units (HUs). These goods movements are posted to the warehouse and to Inventory Management at the same time using movement type 101 or 102, or your own movement type that has been created as a copy of these movement types. For more information on these enhancements, please read the Help Portal page linked here.

CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENTS

Our commitment to modernization and continuous improvements not only enhances functionality but also provides users with a seamless and intuitive interaction, helping businesses drive efficiency, optimize processes, and deliver superior experiences to their stakeholders. To that end, I would like to highlight the following feature.

Reverse Goods Receipt after Final Putaway for Stock from External Procurement

With this feature, you can also reverse goods receipt for stock from external procurement even after final putaway. The reversal is available in the warehouse monitor, as the Reverse after Putaway method in the nodes for physical stocks, for example, Stock and Bin > Physical Stock.

You can also use the API interface /SCWM/IF_API_RVS_STOCK_PTWY in a custom development to perform the reversal. If you are using decentralized SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, and your processes use Logistics Execution (LE) deliveries, you must set the Control Process: Extended Reversal After Final Putaway field to Allow for Completed LE Delivery in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Interfaces > ERP Integration > ERP Integration for Decentralized EWM > Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control.

The Business Add-In (BAdI) Reverse Goods Receipt after Final Putaway (External Procurement) allows you to implement additional checks at reversal of goods receipt after final putaway. See Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for Extended Warehouse Management > Cross-Process Settings > Goods Movement Postings > BAdI: Reverse Goods Receipt after Final Putaway.

ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE IN WAREHOUSE MANAGEMENT

Predictive Labor Demand Planning

With the SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 release, we delivered the foundation of predictive labor demand planning (LDP) that we’ve been able to predict planned workload on Outbound Delivery Order and Warehouse Order/Warehouse Task level based on historical data collected from RF Picking and Packing activities. With this release, you can now use machine learning empowered workload forecast to anticipate future labor needs for better operational planning and resource allocation. The solution uses a minimum of 3 weeks of historical data and predicts the short-term labor demand in next days or weeks. Using SAP Smart Business dashboards, it gives insights of workload duration, calculated Full-time-equivalents (FTE) and other important aspects such as volume, weight, and number of expected items. The feature also takes factory calendar into consideration and offers extensibility possibilities that allow customers to influence on forecast calculations, making the solution adaptable to various warehouse environments.

Joule Navigation & Integration to the Warehouse Outbound Process

There is more to discuss regarding AI features available to EWM this year, but as the Joule development and release schedule has a different cadence to our regular mainline developments and releases, we feel that this topic deserves its own separate blog post. We will revisit later this fall and discuss more details on how Joule can assist both new and seasoned warehouse operators alike in navigating to required documents and FIORI apps, as well as help them throughout the warehouse outbound process. Stay tuned for more.

FIND OUT MORE!

To see more details on the above-mentioned topics as well as see what other enhancements we delivered with this release, I highly encourage you to explore our latest “SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition” slide deck.

You can also find more technical details and documentation on the above listed topic and others we left out via the “What’s New” viewer on the Help Documentation portal.

For more information about SAP Extended Warehouse Management, please follow us on social media, our YouTube channel or our community pages:

SAP EWM Community

SAP Extended Warehouse Management Roadmap Explorer

Release information and restrictions of Decentralized EWM on SAP S/4HANA 2025

entry.title: SAPUI5 TreeTable: Expand All Children of Selected Nodes
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with the SAPUI5 TreeTable, one common requirement is to let users expand nodes beyond just the first level. For example, you may want to expand all children of a selected node, and continue expanding until you reach the deepest leaf level.

The standard SAPUI5 TreeTable API gives us some basic expand/collapse options like expandToLevel() or expanding only specific row index, but there’s no direct way to say:

👉🏼“Take these selected nodes and expand everything under them, no matter how many levels deep.”

That’s exactly the problem I ran into.

To solve this, I built a solution where all selected nodes are expanded recursively until their leaf nodes are visible. The logic works with JSON models (and technically also with OData if you load all hierarchy data upfront — with the usual performance caveats).

Here’s a quick demo of the feature in action 👇🏼

Recursive expansion ensures all children are opened — no matter how deep the hierarchy goes.

 At first, I assumed there must be a ready-made API for this — but there isn’t. So, I decided to build a small recursive helper to achieve this behavior. In this blog, I’ll share how I extended the official TreeTable sample to add this functionality.

Why This Is Useful

TreeTables are often used for things like:

  • Product catalogs

  • Bill of Materials (BOM)

  • Organizational hierarchies

And in all these cases, users don’t just want to expand one level at a time — they often want to open everything under a node they’re interested in.

My Approach

The standard TreeTable APIs include:

  • collapseAll()

  • expandToLevel(level)

  • expand(rowIndex)

They don’t include a “recursive expand” option. So, I wrote a helper function _expandRecursive that expands a node and then walks through all of its children, expanding them one by one.

When recursively expanding multiple selected nodes, the row indices of nodes can change if we start expanding from the top, because expanding a node inserts its child rows and shifts the indices of the rows below it. To prevent this from breaking the expansion of other selected nodes, I sort the selected indices in descending order and expand from the last selected row upwards. Within each node, child nodes are then expanded recursively. The tiny async delay ensures that the TreeTable has time to fully process each expansion before moving to the next child, maintaining correct indexing and avoiding skipped nodes.

Implementation

Controller (CatalogHierarchy.controller.js)

Here’s the core of the solution — notice the onExpandAllLevelsForSelection method and the _expandRecursive helper:

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller"
], (Controller) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("openui5.treetable.recursiveexpand.controller.CatalogHierarchy", {
        onInit() {
        },

         // Collapse all nodes
		onCollapseAll: function() {
			const oTreeTable = this.byId("TreeTableBasic");
			oTreeTable.collapseAll();
		},

        // Collapse only selected nodes
		onCollapseSelection: function() {
			const oTreeTable = this.byId("TreeTableBasic");
			oTreeTable.collapse(oTreeTable.getSelectedIndices());
		},

        // Expand first-level nodes for the entire tree
		onExpandFirstLevelForAll: function() {
			const oTreeTable = this.byId("TreeTableBasic");
			oTreeTable.expandToLevel(1);
		},

        // Expand first-level nodes only for selected entries
		onExpandFirstLevelForSelection: function() {
			const oTreeTable = this.byId("TreeTableBasic");
			oTreeTable.expand(oTreeTable.getSelectedIndices());
		},

        // Expand all levels recursively for selected nodes
        onExpandAllevelsForSelection: function() {
            const oTreeTable = this.byId("TreeTableBasic");
            oTreeTable.setBusyIndicatorDelay(0).setBusy(true);

            const aSelectedIndices = oTreeTable.getSelectedIndices().sort((a, b) => b - a);
		
			// Use a chain of promises to execute the expansion sequentially
			let chain = Promise.resolve();
		
			aSelectedIndices.forEach(function (iIndex) {
				chain = chain.then(function () {
					return this._expandRecursive(oTreeTable, iIndex); // Return a promise from _expandRecursive
				}.bind(this));
			}.bind(this));
		
			chain.then(function () {
				console.log("All selected nodes and their children have been expanded.");
			}).catch(function (error) {
				console.error("Error expanding nodes:", error);
			}).finally(function () {
				oTreeTable.setBusy(false);
			});
		},
		
        /**
         * Recursive function to expand a node and all of its children.
         *  {sap.ui.table.TreeTable} oTreeTable - The TreeTable instance
         *  {int} iIndex - Index of the node to expand
         * @returns {Promise}
         */
		_expandRecursive: function (oTreeTable, iIndex) {
			oTreeTable.expand(iIndex);
		
			const oContext = oTreeTable.getContextByIndex(iIndex);
			if (!oContext) {
				return Promise.resolve();
			}
		
			const iChildCount = oTreeTable.getBinding("rows").getChildCount(oContext);
			let chain = Promise.resolve();
		
			// Process child nodes in reverse order
			for (let i = iChildCount - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
				chain = chain.then(function () {
					const iChildIndex = iIndex + 1 + i;
					return this._asyncDelay(0) // Delay using promises
						.then(() => this._expandRecursive(oTreeTable, iChildIndex));
				}.bind(this));
			}
		
			return chain; // Return the promise chain
		},
		
		/**
         * Helper function to introduce async delay
         *  {int} ms - delay in milliseconds
         * @returns {Promise}
         */
		_asyncDelay: function (ms) {
			return new Promise(function (resolve) {
				setTimeout(resolve, ms);
			});
		}
    });
});

View (CatalogHierarchy.view.xml)

<mvc:View controllerName="openui5.treetable.recursiveexpand.controller.CatalogHierarchy"
        xmlns="sap.ui.table"
        xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
        xmlns:m="sap.m"
        xmlns:u="sap.ui.unified"
        xmlns:core="sap.ui.core"
        height="100%">
    <m:Page
            showHeader="false"
            enableScrolling="false">
        <m:content>
            <TreeTable
                    id="TreeTableBasic"
                    rows="{path:'/catalog/clothing', parameters: {arrayNames:['categories']}}"
                    selectionMode="MultiToggle"
                    enableSelectAll="true"
                    ariaLabelledBy="title">
                <extension>
                    <m:OverflowToolbar style="Clear">
                        <m:Title id="title" text="Clothing"/>
                        <m:ToolbarSpacer/>
                        <m:Button text="Collapse all" press="onCollapseAll"/>
                        <m:Button text="Collapse selection" press="onCollapseSelection"/>
                        <m:Button text="Expand first level for all" press="onExpandFirstLevelForAll"/>
                        <m:Button text="Expand first level for selection" press="onExpandFirstLevelForSelection"/>
                        <m:Button text="Expand all levels for selection" press="onExpandAllevelsForSelection" type="Emphasized"/>
                    </m:OverflowToolbar>
                </extension>
                <columns>
                    <Column width="13rem">
                        <m:Label text="Categories"/>
                        <template>
                            <m:Text text="{name}" wrapping="false" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                    <Column width="9rem">
                        <m:Label text="Price"/>
                        <template>
                            <u:Currency value="{amount}" currency="{currency}"/>
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                    <Column width="11rem">
                        <m:Label text="Size"/>
                        <template>
                            <m:Select
                                    items="{path: '/sizes', templateShareable: true}"
                                    selectedKey="{size}"
                                    visible="{= !!${size}}"
                                    forceSelection="false">
                                <core:Item key="{key}" text="{value}"/>
                            </m:Select>
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                </columns>
            </TreeTable>
        </m:content>
    </m:Page>
</mvc:View>

Things to Watch Out For

  • Works only if the hierarchy is fully loaded (JSON model, or preloaded OData).

  • Won’t work with lazy loading via navigation.

  • Be careful with very large datasets — expanding thousands of nodes recursively can impact performance.

Wrap Up

This helper solved a real problem for me and might help you if you’re working with hierarchical data in a TreeTable. It’s simple, effective, and can be adapted to your use case.

Feel free to fork the repo or leave feedback in the comments!

📦Source Code: GitHub Repository
🌐Live Demo: Try it out here

entry.title: SAP Document Reporting Compliance Angola
entry.content:
Angola Tax Authorities (Administracao Geral Tributaria) have published the technical specifications for their upcoming eInvoicing requirement, through the release of the Royal Decree (Decreto Executivo) n 683/25 published on 22nd of August 2025, which outlines the software data structure, electronic invoicing model, and technical and procedural specifications.

According to the Angola regulatory framework, taxpayers will need to use a certified electronic invoice software to generate and submit the electronic invoices to the Angola Tax Authority (AGT) in real time. The authenticity and integrity of electronically issued documents are ensured through a digital code defined by the AGT.

Angola Tax authorities will provide access to taxpayers and software producers to an eInvoicing portal (Portal do Parceiro), where specific authorizations will be granted to the parties; a testing phase will be provided. Whilst there was little indication that the deadline for large taxpayers would be delayed further to the 1st of October 2025, finally on 23rd of September, Angola Tax authorities announced a transitional period to adopt the mandate, lasting until the 1st of January 2026. Angola Tax authorities have also announced that the eInvocing portal will be made available to taxpayers by October 6th, 2025. From September 21st 2026, the obligation will be extended to all taxpayers.

As it is the case for the SAF-T mandate in Angola since 2020, the Tax authorities will require that the e-Invoicing software is certified with the Angola Tax authorities and allow for real-time transmission of information to the AGT; the certification will include the validation of the JSON for Invoices (Fatura), Credit Notes (Notas de Crédito), Receipts (Recibos) and Invoice-Receipts (Faturas-Recibo). The authenticity, integrity, and non-repudiation of electronically issued documents are ensured through a digital code defined by the AGT.

Taxpayers will need to enrol for E-invoicing through the AGT portal (Portal do Contribuinte) from where the certificates (Chave Publica e Chave Privada) will be available for download.

eInvoices will also need to have the specific series which needed to be communicated to AGT. Once the eInvoice is sent to AGT, AGT sends back a notification that the invoice was received and subsequently a message that the invoice is valid or invalid and, in case of the latter, the related reason. Once eInvoice is approved, taxpayer can send it to the recipient. AGT does not send the eInvoice to final recipient. eInvoices need to be capable of being printed in PDF including a QR code via the eInvocing software which will enable to check the invoice details.

Below picture depicts the Angola eInvoicing model:

Angola Tax authorities technical specifications for eInvoicing provide 7 different API REST services for integration with SIGT (Integrated Tax management system) and eInvocing softwares:

registerInvoice (registarFactura),

getStatus (obterEstado),

listInvoices (listarFacturas),

consultInvoice (consultarFactura),

requestSeries (solicitarSerie),

listSeries (listarSeries),

validateDocument (validarDocumento).   

Crimson Technology Partners has developed the SAP Document Reporting Compliance solution to respond to the eInvoicing mandate of Angola tax authorities. The solution is meeting the requirements of the Angola Tax authorities, and is ready to connect to the AGT platform, as soon as it is released.

SAP Document Reporting Compliance solutions by Crimson Technology partners respect the principle of consistent user experience across countries and uniform functionality across countries, without introducing any custom program or transaction code.

Our standard SAP Document Reporting Compliance Solution, provides a full staging area for testing, training and handbooks for your organisation, providing the following benefits:

  • Single Global Process using Document Reporting Compliance
  • E2E compliant solution built with the Angola Tax authorities
  • Generation of electronic invoices in XML format (FI, SD) for B2B and B2G
  • Self-billing scenario's
  • FICA and RE-FX billing
  • Manual or automated invoice submission
  • Receiving of e-invoices in XML format and Integration to VIM Software
  • Human Readable PDF in Cockpit for incoming invoices

The following image shows the high-level architecture of SAP Document Reporting Compliance Solution for Angola eInvoicing:

The following image shows the ERP detail of the outbound and inbound eInvocing process of SAP Document Reporting Compliance Solution for Angola:

The following image shows the ERP detail of the outbound eInvocing process of SAP Document Reporting Compliance Solution for Angola:

The following image shows the ERP detail of the inbound eInvocing process of SAP Document Reporting Compliance Solution for Angola:

Compatible with ECC, S/4HANA & S/4 Cloud, this is another step on the journey of global electronic invoicing across borders, in particular, for Africa where Nigeria just introduced a Peppol aligned eInvoicing system, and Morocco will introduce a pre-clearance model by 2026, following on Ghana, Kenya, and Ivory Coast.

Look out next for our Ivory Coast and Morocco solution!

entry.title: Why the SAC Excel Add-in Matters
entry.content:
Introduction

In today's finance world, despite the rise of cloud platforms and AI-driven analytics, Excel remains deeply embedded in how finance teams work. Research suggests this isn't changing soon. Many organisations still rely on Excel alongside FP&A solutions and spreadsheets remain critical for flexibility, scenario building, and rapid adjustments.

From a consultant perspective, I see this reflected in SAP's product evolution as well. With cloud first strategy, the early years of SAC focused on strengthening core web features. Looking at the roadmap holistically, the last few years there seems a clear acceleration in the excel integration via SAC Excel Add-in as well. In the early years of SAC’s Excel Add-in, I was a bit cautious about recommending it to the clients because even the core features especially for planning were limited. Over the past 2–3 years, the add-in has matured significantly (with still some limitations in place).

Today, it is becoming a strong enabler for adoption in projects where finance teams depend heavily on Excel. Even in some areas, it provides greater flexibility. As an SAP Planning consultant, I personally love being able to use the SAP’s excel library along with excel formulas while designing flexible input templates.  In this blog, we’ll take a closer look at the SAC Excel Add-in’s core features, how to position it in projects, and where it fits into SAP’s roadmap for analytics.

The Evolution of Excel Integration in SAP Analytics

 

Excel integration is not new for SAP but it has been in the agenda for decades:

  • On-premise era: Excel based analytics tools like BEX Analyzer, BPC (EPM add-in) and Analysis for Office (AfO) run on premise.
  • Cloud-first shift: SAC was launched as a cloud-first product in 2015
  • Excel Integration for SAC accelerates: the first SAC Excel add-in appeared in 2020 with beta version with rapid investment in the upcoming years.

SAP makes it clear that its current strategy is cloud-first. In practice what we see in the FP&A project is a cloud first with Excel flexibility. The web interface remains the primary platform offering the full breadth of features including advanced visualisations, AI/ML capabilities, mobile access, collaboration features, workflows. However, I observed many clients still ask for excel integration especially for cases captured in below parts of the blog. SAP appears to have responded to this situation with the SAC Excel Add-in improving significantly. The add-in positioned as the strategic Excel interface for SAC going forward. 2025 July BI statement of direction confirms that AfO remains supported, (and the main excel interface for BW and BPC customers ), but no new features will be delivered. However, SAC Excel Add-in represents SAP's primary excel interface for cloud-based analytics and planning. More details are available along with comparison with AfO here

This positioning reflects a pragmatic approach: rather than forcing finance teams to abandon Excel entirely, SAC excel add in becomes a bridge that combines cloud platform benefits with the Excel interface that finance professionals know and trust.

 

Key Features, Benefits & Limitations

I've grouped the features into 3 comparing Excel Add-in capabilities with the web interface where relevant. Note that all features/limitations reflect the state as of September 2025. The Add-in evolves rapidly, so this focuses on core capabilities rather than an exhaustive list.

Planning & Data Entry

This is where the Excel Add-in has improved most significantly over the past two years with many core planning features now integrated making it a strong complement to the web interface.

  • Bulk data entry with excel formula support.

SAP excel add in supports mass data entry mode but single and fluid entry mode are available on web interface only. These entry modes provide some flexibility for different cases but I personally find “bulk data entry” in SAC excel add in quite smooth. It is not super easy to bring your offline excel data into SAC web templates although now you can copy-paste multiple cells with recent improvements. But real life scenarios require deeper excel integration with offline excel files. Let’s say an opex planner inputting budget data for 100 cost centers might maintain detailed driver calculations offline (regional KPIs, granular assumptions not in the central SAC model). In these type of cases, I have seen that the clients download web template to excel, blend it with their offline data and paste the output back to web. With the Excel Add-in, planners can use native Excel functions (VLOOKUP, FILTER etc.) directly within SAC-connected template to prepare and validate data before submission. This helps bridging the gap between centralized SAC planning models and the localized dataset that remain in Excel during implementations.

  • Top-down or bottom-up planning.

Disaggregation function is available on excel add in and works the same way with web. If the cells are empty, the system will disaggregate equally else proportionally.

  • Triggering SAC calculations

Triggering data actions are supported including selection parameters. Multi actions are not supported at the moment which makes some cross model copy / calculation steps less flexible but it is in roadmap for Q2-26

  • SAC Formula library for Excel

The SAC Excel Add-in provides SAC-specific formulas (functions with the SAP. prefix) that enable advanced template capabilities. For example, SAP.GETDATA fetches a specific dataset, which helps build reports at cell level. SAP.MEMBERPROPERTY returns the property value of a specific dimension in the frontend to consume these values further (such as version start and end date). There are many other formulas for specific scenarios.

Combining these SAC formulas with Excel's native formula library (IFs, VLOOKUPs, etc.) provides great flexibility. A powerful application of this flexibility is asymmetric filtering. For instance a finance planner starts the budget process with September closed actuals and needs an input template with 9 months actuals + 3 months forecast + 12 months budget (very typical), here the web's "forecast layout" functionality is quite helpful. However, asymmetric filtering in the SAC Excel Add-in takes this further allowing developers to manage different template sections independently, each with its own time horizon and formula logic. See this great blog for detailed guidance on asymmetric filter function in the SAC Excel Add-in.

  • Value Driver Tree: VDT is a web feature so it is not accessible in excel interface.
  • Comments : Data point comments are supported, but don't work on tables where asymmetric filter functionality is used
  • Calendar: Excel workbooks integrate with web-based calendars, but accessing the calendar requires the web interface

Analytics

The Excel Add-in focuses on tabular data analysis, giving finance users a familiar environment to explore SAC data with Excel's formatting and analytical capabilities. For dashboards and advanced visualizations, use the web interface—Excel is not a replacement for SAC's visualization layer

  • Core analytical operations : filters, drill-downs, sorting, and ranking available on SAC excel add in.
  • Formatting: Applying conditional formatting and thresholds are supported. Custom formatting is also possible supported by pre-built styling rules similar with AfO. You can select a master data in the table and apply specific format such as displaying actuals as grey (to highlight it is locked )while keeping other versions white.
  • High-volume mode will support more than 1 million cells soon (a planned Q4-25 only for analytics but not for planning).
  • Restricted measures are supported but calculated measures not yet. Although not the same thing, you can still use add rows / columns functionality and write formulas instead
  • AI / ML Features: Just ask, predictive planning, smart insights etc are accessed only via web add in
  • Advanced visualizations: Dashboards, charts, geo maps etc available on web only.

Collaboration Features

  • Excel add in is not supported on mobile devices. Works on desktop or web version of Office 365
  • Data point comments: Supported in Excel Add-in (with limitation: doesn't work with asymmetric table functionality)
  • Calendar: Excel workbooks integrate with web-based calendars; accessing calendar requires web interface
  • Discussion Panel: Chat is possible via chat only, not available on excel

 

When to Recommend the Excel Add-in

The Excel Add-in is not designed to replace the SAC web interface. Instead, it complements it by providing a familiar interface for Excel-dependent users. It can serve as an adoption enabler and a functional extension of SAC's capabilities.

Recommend the Excel Add-in for:

  • Bulk data preparation - Where finance teams need to manipulate large datasets, combine offline calculations with SAC data, use Excel functions to prepare data before submission.
  • Finance teams heavily reliant on excel - Finance teams who work primarily in Excel and would face significant change management challenges with a web-only interface.
  • Specific cases where excel add in provides more flexibility such as combining SAC's formula library with Excel's native capabilities enabling dynamic time horizons via asymmetric filtering described above.

Project guidance:

To maximize the value of the Excel Add-in:

  • Prototype early, ideally during the Explore phase. This allows you to position the Excel Add-in more accurately, identify which processes truly benefit, and set appropriate expectations with stakeholders.
  • Assess processes criticality. Not all planning processes require deep Excel integration—some may be better served by the web interface alone.
  • Frame it as 'SAC with Excel flexibility' rather than an either/or choice, emphasizing the web as the primary platform with Excel as a strategic complement for specific scenarios

 

Conclusion

Excel is not disappearing from finance. The SAC Excel Add-in addresses this reality by providing a bridge between modern SAC platform and the tool that finance teams trust. The add-in has evolved significantly over the past 2-3 years, with robust planning and core analytics capabilities that make it a genuine complement to the web interface, not a workaround.

In practice, its value goes beyond Excel-dependent teams or bulk data preparation. It also helps organisations manage change, easing the transition to cloud planning & analytics by letting users work in a familiar environment. Framing it as “SAC with Excel flexibility” where the web interface remains the primary platform creates the right balance between innovation and familiarity. This approach helps organisations modernise their planning and analytics while keeping the comfort and agility of Excel.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Payroll Result(Pay-slip) Integration Guide with Third Party Payroll System
entry.content:
This post shares a practical integration case on SuccessFactors MDF Payroll Result (Pay-slip) Integration. It covers how to design MDF objects to store pay-slip data from third-party payroll systems, the integration architecture, and global payroll result analysis design, along with key considerations and limitations. While it appears simple, complexity arises with large data volumes, multiple payroll systems, and diverse data structures.

Background

In this case, the customer is a multinational enterprise using SuccessFactors as a global HRIS, but with different payroll systems per region. As payroll data resides in local systems, the headquarters lacked consolidated insight into workforce costs, limiting analytics and planning. Therefore, centralizing payroll data became essential.

  • Global HRIS: SAP SuccessFactors(Employee Master Data Source)

  • Third-party payroll systems:

    • ADP (US, Mexico)
    • BIPO (APAC: Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam)
    • Payroll B (Germany)

The flow is bidirectional — employee master data moves from SAP SuccessFactors to payroll systems, and pay-slip data flows back into SuccessFactors.

Integration Center / SFTP acts as the middleware.

Pay results land in MDF objects (PayResultParent, PayResultItem) and feed into Story / People Analytics for HQ insights.

Business Requirement Analysis

The table below summarizes the requirements, reasoning, implementation approach, and complexity level.

RequirementCategoryReasoningHow to Achieve Difficulty (1–5) Notes
UI must be user-friendly; HR and employees can view pay slips in Employee ProfileMDF DesignMultiple records per month, with history & audit trailUse effective-dated parent-child MDF entity (version history = completed)2 
Non-eligible allowance/pay result items must be deleted in the relevant monthIntegrationPrevent inheritance of obsolete records
• Use API deletion method:
• purgeType=record for parent MDF;
• purgeType=full for child MDF in Integration Center		5Avoid pushing zero-amount records and invalid record — it creates excessive invalid data.
Analysis should support both local and global pay result itemsMDF DesignMapping between local and global pay result items is neededUse MDF (not Picklist); create custom attributes for analysis3 
Pay amounts should support analysis by month, BU, department, job grade, etc.MDF DesignRequires linking MDF with employee master dataParent MDF externalCode field type = User2 
Integration should support re-updates (back pay or corrections)MDF DesignexternalCode should be meaningful for referencingUse local payroll record ID or rule-generated code (e.g., userId+effectiveDate+allowance)4SuccessFactors External Code Design Best Practice

MDF Table Design

TableFieldNameField Type
cust_PayResultParentapplicantUserAutomatically populated
cust_PayResultParenteffectiveDateDate 
cust_PayResultItemexternalCodeStringUse local payroll record ID for cross-system lookup; if null, auto-generate by concatenating UserId, AllowanceCode, PayrollDate.
cust_PayResultItemcurrencyGOUse standard SF currency MDF
cust_PayResultItemlocalPayResultItemGO 
cust_PayResultItemamountDecimalUse decimal for payroll amounts
cust_PayResultItempayEffectiveDateDateSupports back pay scenarios (e.g., overtime in July paid in September).
cust_PayResultItemamountConversionDecimalAuto-calculated by business rule referencing exchange rate

Not Recommended Design: Using a single MDF for multi-country company with large amount of actual pay component is not scalable or analysis-friendly.

Table Field Name Field Type Notes

cust_PayResultapplicantUserAutomatically populated
cust_PayResulteffectiveDateDate 
cust_PayResultbaseSalaryAmountDecimal 
cust_PayResultcarAllowanceAmountDecimalToo many predefined fields required
cust_PayResultcurrencyGO 

Integration Design

Payroll data can be integrated via API or SFTP.
SFTP is generally recommended because it is auditable (via stored flat files), simple in structure, and suitable for low-frequency data transfers (weekly or monthly).

1. API Integration

In case API integration is required due to security necessity or other, I also introduce API-based integration menthod. In this method, avoid inserting parent and child MDF records in one request. Use two separate upsert requests — one for the parent and another for the child — for clarity, completeness, and broader parameter support. Below is a example of single MDF payload request:

{
  "__metadata": {
    "uri": "https://api4preview.sapsf.com/odata/v2/PaymentInformationV3",
    "type": "SFOData.PaymentInformationV3"
  },
  "effectiveStartDate": "/Date(1753432694289)/",
  "worker": "Berg01",
  "toPaymentInformationDetailV3": {
    "results": [
      {
        "__metadata": {
          "uri": "https://api4preview.sapsf.com/odata/v2/PaymentInformationDetailV3",
          "type": "SFOData.PaymentInformationDetailV3"
        },
        "PaymentInformationV3_effectiveStartDate": "/Date(1753432694289)/",
        "PaymentInformationV3_worker": "Berg01",
        "paySequence": "0",
        "cust_bank": "BBVA"
      },
      {
        "__metadata": {
          "uri": "https://api4preview.sapsf.com/odata/v2/PaymentInformationDetailV3",
          "type": "SFOData.PaymentInformationDetailV3"
        },
        "PaymentInformationV3_effectiveStartDate": "/Date(1753432694289)/",
        "PaymentInformationV3_worker": "Berg01",
        "paySequence": "0",
        "cust_bank": "CHNN"
      }
    ]
  }
}

2.Integration Center (SFTP)

Parent–child MDF integration cannot be handled in a single job. Below shows the comparison of purge types in different operation environment for referrence:

Import Integration Center API Result

Parent Object = Full PurgeParent–Child payload in one API (Full Purge)Parent–Child payload in one job (Full Purge)All existing data cleared and the payload data inserted
Parent = Incremental, Child = IncrementalParent = Incremental, Child = FullpurgeType=record (parent), purgeType=full (child)Old records cleared in the new effective record, new inserted
 Parent = Incremental, Child = IncrementalpurgeType=incrementalPrevious records inherited

Although two jobs are required, the third-party system can still produce one file, as overlapping fields exist between parent and child MDFs and SuccessFactors integration job could consume the single job.

In addition, it is recommended to set source page size to '1000' to make it stable and efficient.

Incorrect Setup (Single Job):

Correct Setup:
Parent Job:

Child Job:

Story and Analysis

Currency Exchange:
Avoid calculating via Story Concatenation Columns — large datasets exceed system limits.
Refer to Guardrails for People Analytics Story and SAP Note 3025688.
Each query supports:

  • Up to 120 columns
  • 30 tables
  • 1,000,000 cells per query

Monthly Aggregation:
To analyze sums per month, use a calculated column (Payroll Month) to convert MM/DD/YYYY → YYYY-MM with Year() and Month() functions.
This handles varying pay frequencies (e.g., bi-weekly in the US vs. monthly in Singapore) efficiently via pivot aggregation.

Historical Record Retrieval:
Use Time Filter for all historical MDF data but “Today” filters for navigation tables (Job Info, Personal Info, etc.) to avoid duplication and incorrect joins.

Summary

This project demonstrates a complex yet practical scenario integrating MDF, API, Integration Center, and Story Reporting. The challenges stemmed from data volume, multiple payroll systems, and sensitivity concerns. It took approximately two months for me to complete the full implementation, so I hope that this guide helps you reduce your learning curve for similar integration requirements.
For detailed questions or discussion, feel free to comment below or contact me in LinkedIn.

entry.title: Re: Free of Charge Material from Customer with Freight an...
entry.content:
I could see the below challenges in your process

  • FOC Raw Materials: Received without invoice value, tracked only by quantity.
  • Associated Costs: Freight and Import Duty are incurred and need to be reflected in product costing.
  • Standard Cost Estimate: Should include these costs in the cost structure of Semi-Finished Goods (SFG) and Finished Goods (FG).

Below are the approaches which you can explore

Even if the material is FOC, you can still create a Purchase Order (PO) with zero material value. Add Freight and Import Duty as condition types in the PO (e.g., FRB1 for freight, ZIMP for import duty). These condition types can be configured to post to specific cost elements.

Use Planned Delivery Costs in the PO to record freight/import duty. These costs can be posted to a cost center or internal order using account assignment. Ensure these costs are not capitalized to inventory but are available for cost analysis.

In SAP CO-PC, define a costing sheet that includes surcharges for freight and import duty. Link these surcharges to cost elements that capture the actuals from the PO or customs. This allows the standard cost estimate to include these costs even if the RM is non-valuated.

Create a phantom material or auxiliary material to represent the FOC RM. Assign freight/import duty costs to this material manually or via costing sheet. Include this in the BOM of the SFG/FG so the cost flows into the final product.

Your configuration approach should be

  • Ensure cost elements for freight and import duty are created and assigned to appropriate cost component structure.
  • Use valuation class and account determination to route costs correctly.
  • Consider using Activity Types if freight is internal (e.g., company trucks).

So with the above, the outcome is by using planned delivery costs, costing sheets, and manual cost component planning, your costing team can ensure that Freight and Import Duty for FOC raw materials are included in the standard cost estimate—even though the material itself is non-valuated.

entry.title: Re: Restrict users from editing a parked invoice
entry.content:
To achieve this, you’ll need to modify the business role assigned to the users by adjusting the access category and restriction types in the Maintain Business Roles app.

Open the “Maintain Business Roles” app in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Identify the role assigned to users who should not edit parked invoices. Navigate to the “Maintain Restrictions” tab for that role. Locate the business catalog related to supplier invoice processing (e.g., SAP_FIN_BC_AP_INV_PROC_PC). Under Access Categories, set Write Access → No Access or Restricted (depending on whether you want full block or conditional access). Read Access → Unrestricted (so they can still view parked invoices).

In Restriction Types, look for fields like Invoice Status, Company Code, Document Type, Posting Status. Set these to restrict editing based on parked status or other relevant criteria.

entry.title: SAP FICO Career Scope in India 2025: Opportunities, Growth & Skills You Need
entry.content:
Introduction

If you’ve ever wondered how large companies manage their finances seamlessly, there’s a good chance SAP FICO is behind it. As digital transformation accelerates across Indian enterprises, best SAP FICO career opportunities are booming in 2025. Whether you’re a student exploring future-proof career options or a fresher seeking specialization, SAP FICO offers the perfect blend of technology, finance, and business understanding.

In this guide, we’ll explore everything you need to know about SAP FICO’s career scope in India—what skills you need, how much you can earn, what the job roles look like, and how to start learning it the right way.

What is SAP FICO and Why It is having career scope in India 2025?

SAP FICO stands for Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO)—two of the most critical modules in the SAP ERP suite. It helps organizations manage their financial transactions, budgeting, and internal cost control.

In simple terms, SAP FICO professionals are the bridge between business finance and technology. As Indian companies migrate from legacy systems to SAP S/4HANA, skilled FICO consultants are becoming indispensable.

Why it’s trending in 2025:

  • India’s digital finance landscape is expanding rapidly.
  • SMEs and large corporations are moving to cloud-based ERP systems.
  • SAP-certified professionals earn some of the highest packages in enterprise IT.
  • Global consulting firms (like Deloitte, Capgemini, Accenture) are actively hiring SAP FICO specialists.

Career Opportunities in SAP FICO

  1. SAP FICO Consultant

The most common role, responsible for configuring and maintaining the SAP FICO module according to client needs. Consultants also handle system upgrades, business process mapping, and end-user training.

Average Salary: ₹6–12 LPA for mid-level professionals.

  1. SAP FICO Analyst

Analysts focus on data reporting, financial reconciliations, and supporting business decisions through analytics. They act as the link between finance teams and IT departments.

Average Salary: ₹4–8 LPA depending on experience and company type.

  1. SAP FICO End User

End users work within the finance departments of companies using SAP. They perform day-to-day activities like posting entries, generating reports, and monitoring transactions.

Average Salary: ₹3–6 LPA (ideal starting point for fresh graduates).

  1. SAP FICO Trainer or Instructor

With demand for FICO training increasing, becoming an SAP FICO tutor is another rewarding path. Trainers earn both through corporate batches and online teaching platforms.

Average Salary: ₹8–15 LPA (or ₹800–₹2,000/hour for freelance trainers).

SAP FICO Career Growth Path

A career in SAP FICO is not static. With continuous upskilling, you can move up the ladder:

  1. Junior Consultant (0–2 years) – Learn configurations, testing, and documentation.
  2. Senior Consultant (2–5 years) – Handle implementation and client interactions.
  3. Team Lead / Project Manager (5–8 years) – Oversee end-to-end SAP projects.
  4. Solution Architect (8+ years) – Design integrated solutions across SAP modules.
  5. SAP Practice Head / Functional Lead (10+ years) – Lead enterprise-wide strategy and consulting.

Skills Required to Build a Strong SAP FICO Career

Skill Type

Example / Description

Technical Skills

SAP FICO configuration, S/4HANA migration, integration with MM/SD/PP modules

Finance Knowledge

Accounting principles, cost center management, asset accounting

Analytical Thinking

Problem-solving, business analysis, and data interpretation

Communication

Client coordination, documentation, and presentation

Certifications

SAP Certified Application Associate (S/4HANA for Financial Accounting)

Pro Tip: Many successful consultants start with accounting degrees (B.Com, MBA Finance, CA-Inter) and then specialize in SAP FICO.

SAP FICO Salary Trends in India (2025 Update)

Experience Level

Role

Average Salary (₹ per annum)

0–2 years

SAP FICO End User / Junior Consultant

₹3–5 LPA

3–5 years

SAP FICO Consultant

₹6–10 LPA

5–8 years

Senior Consultant

₹10–16 LPA

8+ years

Project Manager / Architect

₹18–30 LPA

Top-paying cities for SAP FICO professionals:
Bangalore, Hyderabad, Pune, Chennai, and Gurgaon.

SAP FICO Learning Roadmap for Students

  1. Step 1: Build foundational knowledge in Accounting & ERP concepts.
  2. Step 2: Learn the core SAP FICO modules (General Ledger, Accounts Payable, Cost Center Accounting).
  3. Step 3: Practice hands-on using SAP S/4HANA trial systems.
  4. Step 4: Enroll in advanced courses with practical case studies.
  5. Step 5: Earn certification and build your portfolio with mini projects.
  6. Step 6: Apply for internships or freelance projects to gain experience.

👉 Tip: Compare verified SAP FICO tutors in online on FindMyGuru to learn from experienced trainers who provide real-time project exposure.

Why SAP FICO Is a Safe & Future-Proof Career in India

  • Evergreen Domain: Finance and controlling are vital for every business.
  • Cloud Adoption: S/4HANA Cloud is driving new implementations.
  • Global Demand: Opportunities across India, Middle East, Europe, and North America.
  • High ROI on Learning: Short learning curve but high salary potential.
  • Cross-domain Mobility: You can transition into SAP CO, MM, or S/4HANA Finance roles later.

SAP FICO vs Other SAP Modules – Which Should You Choose?

Aspect

SAP FICO

SAP MM

Career Stability

Salary Growth

Excellent

If you have a commerce or finance background, SAP FICO is undoubtedly the best starting point.

FAQs About SAP FICO Career

  1. Is SAP FICO a good career for beginners?
    Yes. Even fresh graduates from commerce or MBA backgrounds can start as end users or junior consultants. With consistent learning, you can grow into consulting or management roles.
  2. How long does it take to learn SAP FICO?
    Typically, 3–6 months of structured training with practical projects is sufficient to become job-ready, provided you have basic accounting knowledge.
  3. What is the future of SAP FICO in India after 2025?
    The demand will continue to grow as more companies shift to SAP S/4HANA. Certified consultants will have global opportunities and higher salary packages.
  4. Can non-commerce students learn SAP FICO?
    Yes. While finance basics help, students from technical backgrounds can also learn with the right guidance and structured training.
  5. How can I find the best SAP FICO trainer?
    You can compare verified SAP FICO tutors and institutes on FindMyGuru, check reviews, and book demo sessions before enrolling.

Conclusion

The best SAP FICO career landscape in India is brighter than ever in 2025. With digital transformation touching every industry—from manufacturing to retail—companies need experts who can translate financial data into business decisions.

If you’re passionate about finance, technology, and problem-solving, SAP FICO can be your gateway to a stable, high-paying career.

👉 Compare verified SAP FICO tutors on FindMyGuru and start your learning journey today.

Visit: https://www.findmyguru.com/sap-fico-tutors-in-online

entry.title: Some ACDOCA entries missing in ACDOCU after GRPL (Release Universal Journals)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,
we’re using S/4HANA On-Premise Group Reporting and performing the release via the GRPL (Release Universal Journals) process. In general, we can see that most G/L accounts — such as bank accounts and trade receivables — are transferred completely and correctly from ACDOCA to ACDOCU. However, for some accounts like advances given to suppliers or finished goods, we’ve noticed that certain records are missing in ACDOCU. Even though these accounts belong to the same ledger, period, version, and G/L setup, only part of the ACDOCA entries are released — while specific document lines are skipped during the data load. When we trace the skipped document numbers in ACDOCA, we also find that their offsetting credit entries (for example, trade payables) are missing in ACDOCU as well. This is one example, but we’ve identified a few similar cases. FS Item mapping and all other configuration steps seem correct, and we’ve also executed the Realign Group Reporting Preparation Ledger job as part of our checks. Has anyone experienced this kind of issue — where certain ACDOCA document lines are silently skipped during the GRPL release — or knows what could cause this behavior?
